section.title: Communications with banking customers and financial promotions

rules.rawText: A firm must ensure that a communication or financial promotion relating to a retail banking product or service is clear, fair and not misleading.

obligations.actionText: Must ensure all communications and financial promotions for retail banking products are clear, fair and not misleading
obligations.objectText: All communications and financial promotions relating to retail banking products and services
obligations.conditionText: When communicating with or promoting to banking customers
obligations.summary: All banking product communications and promotions must be clear, fair and not misleading. This applies to advertising, product literature, terms and conditions, and all customer correspondence.

rules.rawText: Where a distance contract for a retail banking service is concluded, the firm must provide the banking customer with the terms and conditions of that contract in a durable medium in good time either before the conclusion of the contract, or immediately after the conclusion of the contract where the contract has been concluded at the banking customer's request using a means of distance communication which does not enable the provision of the terms and conditions in that manner.

obligations.actionText: Must provide terms and conditions in a durable medium before or immediately after conclusion of a distance contract
obligations.objectText: Full terms and conditions of the distance contract for the retail banking service
obligations.conditionText: When concluding a distance contract for a retail banking service
obligations.summary: When banking products are sold at a distance (online, phone), full terms must be provided in a durable medium either before or immediately after the contract is made.

clauseTemplate.title: Distance Contract Terms
clauseTemplate.templateText: If you opened this account online, by phone or through another distance channel, we will provide you with the full terms and conditions in writing (by post or email) either before or immediately after the account is opened. You have the right to receive a paper copy of these terms at any time on request.
clauseTemplate.guidance: Durable medium includes email and downloadable PDF but must allow the customer to store and reproduce the information unchanged. Ensure digital delivery meets the durable medium test.

section.title: Information to be provided to banking customers

rules.rawText: A firm must provide or make available to a banking customer appropriate information about a retail banking product or service and any charges in good time before, during, and after the contract for the product or service has been entered into.

obligations.actionText: Must provide appropriate product and charges information in good time before, during and after the contract
obligations.objectText: Appropriate information about the retail banking product, its features and any charges
obligations.conditionText: Before, during and after the customer has entered into the banking contract
obligations.summary: Banks must provide customers with appropriate product and charges information at all stages: pre-sale, at point of sale, and on an ongoing basis throughout the life of the account.

clauseTemplate.title: Ongoing Information Provision
clauseTemplate.templateText: We will provide you with clear information about this account and any charges that apply: (a) before you open the account — a summary of key features, interest rates and charges; (b) when you open the account — the full terms and conditions; (c) during the life of the account — regular statements, notification of changes to rates or charges, and an annual summary of charges applied. You can request information about your account at any time.
clauseTemplate.guidance: BCOBS 4 requires ongoing information, not just pre-sale. Annual statements of charges are particularly important for current accounts. Ensure interest rate changes are communicated promptly.

rules.rawText: A firm should provide a banking customer with information about the interest rate that applies to a retail banking product and information that will enable the banking customer to identify the interest rate that will apply if the current rate changes, including a statement of any relevant base rate or reference rate.

obligations.actionText: Should provide information about the applicable interest rate and how it may change, including the reference rate
obligations.objectText: Interest rate information including current rate, basis of rate and reference to any base rate or reference rate
obligations.conditionText: When providing product information to banking customers
obligations.summary: Banks should clearly disclose the current interest rate, how it is determined, and what will happen if it changes, including reference to any base rate that the product rate follows.

clauseTemplate.title: Interest Rate Disclosure
clauseTemplate.templateText: The interest rate on this account is [X]% AER / [X]% gross per annum. [This is a variable rate linked to the Bank of England base rate / This is a fixed rate that applies until [date]]. We will tell you the current rate at any time on request and publish it on our website. If the rate changes, we will notify you [before the change takes effect / within 30 days].
clauseTemplate.guidance: Must include AER for savings. For tracker products, clearly explain the relationship to the base rate. For easy access savings, consider whether the rate is genuinely competitive versus a teaser that drops.

rules.rawText: A firm must provide or make available to a banking customer statements relating to a retail banking product at least annually in a durable medium, or more frequently if agreed or required by the terms of the product.

obligations.actionText: Must provide account statements at least annually in a durable medium
obligations.objectText: Account statements for retail banking products
obligations.conditionText: On an ongoing basis, at least annually
obligations.summary: Banks must provide account statements at least once a year in a durable medium. More frequent statements may be required by the product terms or customer agreement.

clauseTemplate.title: Account Statements
clauseTemplate.templateText: We will provide you with account statements at least once a year. For current accounts, we provide monthly statements. Statements are available online through our banking app and website, and you can request paper statements at any time. Your statement will show all transactions, interest applied and any charges.
clauseTemplate.guidance: Durable medium is required. Online statements accessible through a login are generally considered durable. Ensure customers can easily access historical statements.

rules.rawText: When a firm proposes to vary the terms of the contract for a retail banking product to the significant disadvantage of the banking customer, the firm must provide the banking customer with at least 60 days' notice before the change takes effect.

obligations.actionText: Must give at least 60 days' notice of changes to banking product terms that are significantly disadvantageous to the customer
obligations.objectText: Notification of changes to retail banking product terms and conditions
obligations.conditionText: When varying contract terms to the significant disadvantage of the banking customer
obligations.summary: Changes to banking product terms that significantly disadvantage the customer require at least 60 days' advance notice. This includes rate reductions on savings and increases to charges.

clauseTemplate.title: Notice of Adverse Changes
clauseTemplate.templateText: If we need to make a change to your account terms that is significantly disadvantageous to you, we will give you at least 60 days' written notice before the change takes effect. This includes changes such as reducing interest rates or increasing charges. We will explain the change clearly and tell you how it affects you. You will have the right to close your account or switch to a different product before the change takes effect without penalty.
clauseTemplate.guidance: The 60-day notice period is a minimum for significantly disadvantageous changes. Consider what constitutes 'significant disadvantage' — interest rate reductions on savings, new charges, and removal of benefits are clear examples.

rules.rawText: A firm must ensure that a banking customer can move from one retail banking product to another retail banking product with the same firm, or to a different firm, without unreasonable barriers or delay.

obligations.actionText: Must enable customers to switch products or providers without unreasonable barriers or delay
obligations.objectText: Customer switching processes between products and between providers
obligations.conditionText: When a banking customer wishes to switch products or providers
obligations.summary: Banks must not create unreasonable barriers to switching, whether the customer is moving to another product at the same bank or switching to a different provider entirely.

clauseTemplate.title: Switching and Account Closure
clauseTemplate.templateText: You are free to switch this account to a different product with us, or to move to a different bank or building society, at any time. We will not place unreasonable barriers in your way. For current accounts, the Current Account Switch Service (CASS) provides a free and simple switching process that completes within 7 working days. For savings accounts, we will transfer your balance within [X] working days of your request.
clauseTemplate.guidance: CASS compliance is essential for current accounts. For savings, ensure closure and transfer processes are genuinely straightforward with no unnecessary delays or requirements.

rules.rawText: Where a distance contract for a retail banking product is concluded, the banking customer has a right to cancel the contract within 14 days beginning on the day after the day on which the contract is concluded.

obligations.actionText: Must provide a 14-day cancellation right for distance contracts for retail banking products
obligations.objectText: The right to cancel a distance contract within 14 days
obligations.conditionText: When a retail banking product is sold via a distance channel
obligations.summary: Customers who open banking products at a distance (online, phone) have a 14-day cooling-off period during which they can cancel the contract.

clauseTemplate.title: 14-Day Cancellation Right
clauseTemplate.templateText: If you opened this account online, by telephone or through another distance channel, you have the right to cancel within 14 days of opening the account. To cancel, contact us by [phone/online/in writing]. If you cancel, we will return any money in the account to you or to your nominated account. You will receive any interest earned up to the date of cancellation.
clauseTemplate.guidance: The 14-day right applies to distance contracts only. Ensure the cancellation process is simple and that interest is calculated fairly up to the cancellation date.

rules.rawText: A firm providing banking services to business customers, including micro-enterprises, must ensure that communications are appropriate to the nature and complexity of the business customer's banking arrangements.

obligations.actionText: Must ensure business banking communications are appropriate to the nature and complexity of the customer's banking arrangements
obligations.objectText: All communications with business banking customers including account correspondence, product information and regulatory notices
obligations.conditionText: When communicating with business banking customers including micro-enterprises and SMEs
obligations.summary: Business banking communications must be tailored to the customer's level of sophistication. Micro-enterprises and smaller SMEs may need simpler language comparable to retail customers, while larger businesses may receive more technical communications.

clauseTemplate.title: Business Banking Communications Standard
clauseTemplate.templateText: We will communicate with you in a way that is clear and appropriate to your business banking needs. Important information about your account, charges and terms will be provided in plain language. If your business is a micro-enterprise (fewer than 10 employees and turnover/balance sheet under €2 million), you will receive the same communication protections as personal banking customers.
clauseTemplate.guidance: FCA expects firms to assess whether business customers are micro-enterprises and to provide appropriate protections. The definition of micro-enterprise follows EU Recommendation 2003/361/EC.

rules.rawText: When providing information about business banking charges, a firm should present charges information in a standardised format that enables the business customer to compare the cost of banking across providers.

obligations.actionText: Should present business banking charges in a standardised format enabling comparison across providers
obligations.objectText: Charges information for business banking products including account fees, transaction charges and overdraft costs
obligations.conditionText: When disclosing charges to business banking customers
obligations.summary: Business banking charges should be presented in a format that allows customers to compare costs between banks. This supports the CMA remedies requiring standardised business banking tariff information.

clauseTemplate.title: Business Banking Charges Disclosure
clauseTemplate.templateText: Our charges for this business account are set out in our Business Tariff, which is available on our website and on request. The tariff covers: (a) monthly account maintenance fees; (b) transaction charges for payments, cash handling and other services; (c) overdraft interest rates and fees; (d) charges for additional services such as international payments and foreign currency transactions. We present our charges in the standardised industry format to help you compare costs with other providers.
clauseTemplate.guidance: The CMA's Retail Banking Market Investigation Order 2017 requires publication of standardised business current account charges. Ensure compliance with both BCOBS and CMA requirements.

rules.rawText: A firm must not create unreasonable barriers to a business banking customer switching their business current account to another provider, and must participate in the Current Account Switch Service where applicable.

obligations.actionText: Must not create unreasonable barriers to business current account switching and must participate in CASS where applicable
obligations.objectText: Business current account switching processes and participation in the Current Account Switch Service
obligations.conditionText: When a business customer wishes to switch their business current account
obligations.summary: Banks must facilitate business current account switching without unreasonable barriers. The Current Account Switch Service (CASS) covers business accounts with a turnover up to £6.5 million. Banks must complete switches within the CASS guarantee timescales.

clauseTemplate.title: Business Account Switching
clauseTemplate.templateText: You can switch your business current account to another bank at any time using the Current Account Switch Service (CASS), provided your business has an annual turnover of up to £6.5 million. The switch will be completed within 7 working days. We will transfer your incoming and outgoing payments to your new account and redirect any payments sent to your old account for 36 months. There is no charge for using the switching service.
clauseTemplate.guidance: CASS is mandatory for eligible business accounts. The £6.5m turnover threshold covers the vast majority of SMEs. Ensure the process is genuinely barrier-free and that closing processes do not delay switching.

rules.rawText: Where a business banking customer gives notice of closure of a business current account, the firm must complete the closure process within a reasonable period and must not charge unreasonable exit fees.

obligations.actionText: Must complete business account closure within a reasonable period and must not charge unreasonable exit fees
obligations.objectText: The account closure process for business current accounts
obligations.conditionText: When a business customer gives notice of closure
obligations.summary: Business account closure must be completed promptly without unreasonable exit charges. This prevents banks from using procedural delays or punitive fees to discourage switching.

clauseTemplate.title: Business Account Closure
clauseTemplate.templateText: You may close this account at any time by giving us [30 days'] written notice. We will process the closure within [X] working days of receiving your notice and transfer any remaining balance to your nominated account. There is no charge for closing your account. Any accrued interest will be paid up to the date of closure.
clauseTemplate.guidance: Closure periods should be genuinely reasonable. The FCA takes a dim view of unreasonable delays or complex closure processes that effectively trap business customers.

section.title: Overdraft and lending to business banking customers

rules.rawText: A firm providing an overdraft facility to a business banking customer must provide clear information about the overdraft terms, including the interest rate, any fees, the overdraft limit, and the consequences of exceeding the limit.

obligations.actionText: Must provide clear information about business overdraft terms including rate, fees, limit and consequences of exceeding the limit
obligations.objectText: Overdraft terms information including interest rate, fees, limit and excess charges
obligations.conditionText: When providing an overdraft facility to a business banking customer
obligations.summary: Business overdraft terms must be clearly disclosed upfront, including the interest rate (EAR), any arrangement or renewal fees, the agreed limit, and what happens if the business goes over the limit. Unarranged overdraft charges must also be clearly stated.

clauseTemplate.title: Business Overdraft Terms
clauseTemplate.templateText: Your business overdraft facility has the following terms: (a) Agreed limit: £[X]; (b) Interest rate: [X]% EAR (variable, linked to [base rate/our reference rate]); (c) Arrangement fee: £[X]; (d) Annual renewal fee: £[X] (if applicable). If you exceed your agreed overdraft limit, additional charges will apply: (i) unarranged overdraft interest at [X]% EAR; (ii) an excess fee of £[X] per [day/month]. We will contact you if your account goes into an unarranged overdraft to discuss your options.
clauseTemplate.guidance: Business overdraft disclosure should mirror the transparency expected for consumer overdrafts. The FCA's 2019 overdraft reforms primarily target personal accounts, but Consumer Duty requires similar fair treatment principles for micro-enterprise customers.

rules.rawText: A firm must give a business banking customer reasonable notice before reducing or withdrawing an overdraft facility, except where there are exceptional circumstances such as fraud or serious breach of terms.

obligations.actionText: Must give reasonable notice before reducing or withdrawing a business overdraft, except in exceptional circumstances
obligations.objectText: Notification of changes to or withdrawal of business overdraft facilities
obligations.conditionText: When a firm decides to reduce or withdraw a business customer's overdraft facility
obligations.summary: Banks must not suddenly reduce or withdraw business overdraft facilities without reasonable notice. This protects businesses from sudden cash flow disruption. Exceptions apply only for fraud or serious terms breaches.

clauseTemplate.title: Changes to Business Overdraft Facility
clauseTemplate.templateText: If we need to reduce or withdraw your overdraft facility, we will give you at least [60/90] days' written notice so you can make alternative arrangements. This notice requirement does not apply if: (a) there has been fraud on your account; (b) you are in serious breach of the overdraft terms; or (c) we are required by law or regulation to act immediately. During the notice period, your existing overdraft limit will remain available to you.
clauseTemplate.guidance: The FCA's Principles for Business (Principle 6 — treating customers fairly) and Consumer Duty require that businesses are given adequate time to arrange alternative funding. The Lending Standards Board's Standards of Lending Practice for business customers provide sector guidance.

rules.rawText: Where a firm provides lending products to business banking customers, including term loans and asset finance, the firm should ensure that key terms are presented clearly and that the total cost of borrowing is disclosed.

obligations.actionText: Should present business lending key terms clearly and disclose the total cost of borrowing
obligations.objectText: Key terms and total cost of borrowing for business lending products including term loans and asset finance
obligations.conditionText: When providing lending products to business banking customers
obligations.summary: Business lending terms should be presented transparently, including the total cost of credit, any fees, the repayment schedule, and early repayment terms. This applies to term loans, asset finance and other commercial lending.

clauseTemplate.title: Business Lending Terms Disclosure
clauseTemplate.templateText: The key terms of this business lending facility are: (a) Facility amount: £[X]; (b) Term: [X] months/years; (c) Interest rate: [X]% per annum [fixed/variable]; (d) Total cost of credit: £[X] (total interest and fees payable over the term); (e) Repayment: [monthly/quarterly] instalments of £[X]; (f) Arrangement fee: £[X]; (g) Early repayment: [subject to an early repayment charge of X% / no early repayment charge]. Security required: [details of any security or guarantee required].
clauseTemplate.guidance: While commercial lending to incorporated businesses may not be CCA-regulated, Consumer Duty expects transparent terms for micro-enterprise borrowers. The Lending Standards Board's Standards apply to business lending. Total cost of credit disclosure helps SMEs make informed borrowing decisions.
